title: The Arequipa Massif of Peru : new SHRIMP and isotope constraints on a Paleoproterozoic inlier in the Grenvillian orogen
abstract:
The enigmatic Arequipa Massif of southwestern Peru is an outcrop of Andean basement that underwent Grenville-age metamorphism, and as such it is important for the better constraint of Laurentia–Amazonia ties in Rodinia reconstruction models. U–Pb SHRIMP zircon dating has yielded new evidence on the evolution of the Massif between Middle Paleoproterozoic and Early Paleozoic. The oldest rock-forming events occurred in major orogenic events between ca. 1.79 and 2.1 Ga (Orosirian to Rhyacian), involving early magmatism (1.89–2.1 Ga, presumably emplaced through partly Archaean continental crust), sedimentation of a thick sequence of terrigenous sediments, UHT metamorphism at ca. 1.87 Ga, and late felsic magmatism at ca. 1.79 Ga. The Atico sedimentary basin developed in the Late-Mesoproterozoic and detrital zircons were fed from a source area similar to the high-grade Paleoproterozoic basement, but also from an unknown source that provided Mesoproterozoic zircons of 1200–1600 Ma. The Grenville-age metamorphism was of low-P type; it both reworked the Paleoproterozoic rocks and also affected the Atico sedimentary rocks. Metamorphism was diachronous: ca. 1040 Ma in the Quilca and Camaná areas and in the San Juán Marcona domain, 940 ± 6 Ma in the Mollendo area, and between 1000 and 850 Ma in the Atico domain. These metamorphic domains are probably tectonically juxtaposed. Comparison with coeval Grenvillian processes in Laurentia and in southern Amazonia raises the possibility that Grenvillian metamorphism in the Arequipa Massif resulted from extension and not from collision. The Arequipa Massif experienced Ordovician–Silurian magmatism at ca. 465 Ma, including anorthosites formerly considered to be Grenvillian, and high-T metamorphism deep within the magmatic arc. Focused retrogression along shear zones or unconformities took place between 430 and 440 Ma.\ud

Abstract18
19
The enigmatic Arequipa massif of southwestern Peru is an outcrop of Andean basement 20

Laurentia–Amazonia ties in Rodinia reconstruction models. U-Pb SHRIMP zircon dating has 22
yielded new evidence on the evolution of the massif between Middle Paleoproterozoic and 23
Early Paleozoic. The oldest rock-forming events occurred in  major orogenic events between 24
ca. 1.79 and 2.1 Ga (Orosirian to Rhyacian), involving early magmatism (1.89–2.1Ga), 25

Introduction45
46
The Arequipa Massif (Cobbing and Pitcher, 1972) is an outcrop of metamorphic rocks and 47
cross-cutting batholiths at least 800 km long and 100 km wide, along the desert coast of48
southern Peru (Shackleton et al., 1979), between the Andean Cordillera and the Chile–Peru 49
trench (Fig. 1). It is part of the Andean basement that outcrops both as discontinuous inliers50

throughout the belt and in uplifted blocks in the Andean foreland, from as far north as51
Venezuela to as far south as the Sierras Pampeanas of Argentina (see Rapela et al., this 52
volume). Metamorphic rocks of the Arequipa Massif are mostly metasedimentary and range 53
from amphibolite to granulite facies. Pervasive retrogression under greenschist facies was54
focused within late strongly sheared zones.  Early dating of granulites between Camaná and 55
Mollendo (Fig. 1) by Rb-Sr (whole-rock isochrons) and U-Pb (bulk dating of zircons) first 56
resulted in Precambrian ages of ca 1.8–1.95 Ga (Cobbing et al., 1977; Dalmayrac et al., 1977; 57
Shackleton et al., 1979). Regional metamorphism in the Arequipa Massif according to these 58
authors resulted from a single Paleoproterozoic tectonothermal event; the age of sedimentary 59
protoliths was estimated at ca. 2000 Ma. Emplacement of plutons and metamorphic 60
reworking under low-grade conditions took place in the Paleozoic at ca. 450 Ma and ca. 390 61
Ma (Shackleton et al., 1979).62
63
Paleogeographic models of Proterozoic continents as developed in the 1990s led to a 64
renewed interest in the study of the Arequipa Massif. According to these models most 65
continental masses reunited into a large supercontinent called Rodinia by the end of the 66
Mesoproterozoic as a result of the Grenvillian orogeny (e.g. Moores, 1991; Hoffman, 1991; 67
Dalziel, 1997). In these models, and in more recent paleogeographical reconstructions, the 68
Amazonia craton figures juxtaposed to Laurentia, i.e., the ancestral North America craton, at69
ca. 1.0 Ga, although their relative positions vary from one to another (e.g., Dalziel, 1997; 70
Davidson, 1995; Loewy et al., 2003; Tohver et al., 2004; Li et al., 2008). Amazonia broke 71
away from Laurentia in the Neoproterozoic, leading to the opening of the Iapetus Ocean and 72
the intervening Grenvillian orogen broke into conjugate belts along the margins of the rifted 73
continents. Because Grenvillian ages were known from elsewhere in South America, lending74
credence to the Laurentia - Amazonia connection in this way, the age, paleogeography and75

tectonics of the Arequipa Massif became the subject of thorough isotope (Nd and Pb) and76
renewed geochronological research (Wasteneys et al., 1995; Tosdal, 1996; Bock et al., 2000; 77
Loewy et al., 2003, 2004). 78
79
U-Pb single-grain zircon dating of granulites yielded Grenvillian ages of ca. 1200 Ma near 80
Quilca, and ca 970 Ma near Mollendo for the high-grade metamorphism, with protolith ages 81
of ca. 1.9 Ga (Wasteneys et al., 1995). The age of regional metamorphism in the Arequipa 82
Massif thus switched from Paleoproterozoic to Late Mesoproterozoic and the massif was re-83
interpreted as having originated within the Grenville province. Further conventional zircon U-84
Pb dating was carried out by Loewy et al. (2004) on igneous gneisses of the San Juán and 85
Mollendo areas. They inferred a complex history of crystallization of protoliths between 1851 86
and 1818 Ma, and at ca. 1790 Ma, with development of an earlier gneissic fabric prior to the 87
latter (M1 metamorphism). Mesoproterozoic metamorphism (M2) took place between ca.88
1052 Ma at San Juán and 935 Ma near Mollendo, suggesting a north-to-south younging of the 89
metamorphic peak. A retrograde metamorphic overprint (M3) and conspicuous granite 90
magmatism took place in the Ordovician at ca. 465 Ma (Loewy et al., 2003). Martignole and 91
Martelat (2003) focused on the structure, geochronology and mineralogy of the high-grade92
metamorphism between Camaná and Mollendo, which they classified as of the UHT type 93
(T>900 ºC; 1.0–1.3 GPa) on account of ubiquitous peak assemblages with 94
orthopyroxene+sillimanite+quartz and the local coexistence of sapphirine+quartz. Dating this 95
metamorphism was attempted by in situ chemical (CHIME) U-Th-Pb determinations on 96
monazites; the calculated ages range from 1064 to 956 (±50) Ma, with a peak ca. 1.0 Ga.97
98
The Arequipa Massif has long been considered to be the northern exposure of a larger99
hypothetical continental block that outcrops as basement inliers within the Andean Cordillera100

in northern Chile and northern Argentina, i.e., the composite Arequipa-Antofalla craton 101
(Ramos, 1988). This block includes a Grenvillian basement and post-Grenvillian 102
metamorphic and igneous overprints as young as 0.4 Ga (Loewy et al., 2003). Isotope (Nd 103
and Pb) and geochronological considerations led Casquet et al. (2008) to establish 104
comparisons between Grenvillian terranes recognized in the Western Sierras Pampeanas, i.e., 105
the Andean foreland, and the Arequipa Massif, thus enlarging the boundaries of the Arequipa-106
Antofalla block. However, both the role of the Arequipa Massif in the Grenvillian orogeny 107
and its pre-Grenvillian history are still poorly known. Wasteneys et al. (1995) were the first to 108
propose that the Arequipa Massif was a promontory of Laurentia accreted to Amazonía 109
during the Sunsás orogeny, a Late Mesoproterozoic Grenvillian-age tectonic event long 110
recognized along the SW margin of Amazonía, in Brasil and SE Bolivia (Litherland et al., 111
1989; Cordani and Teixeira, 2007). According to Wasteneys et al. (1995) granulite 112
metamorphism resulted from pre-collisional subcontinental mantle delamination coeval with 113
flat subduction, and concomitant rise of the hot asthenosphere that heated the overlying 114
continental crust (see also Martignole and Martelat, 2003). However, for Loewy et al. (2004)115
the Arequipa-Antofalla block was an orphaned block, accreted to Amazonia during the 116
Sunsás orogeny at ca. 1.05 Ga.   117
118
It is now widely accepted that the Grenvillian orogenic cycle played an important role in 119
Central Andean South America as evidenced by the Arequipa Massif and the Western Sierras 120
Pampeanas. Moreover Grenvillian-age rocks have long been recognized in the basement of121
the Northern Andes (e.g., Restrepo Pace et al., 1997) and along the southern margin of the 122
Amazonia craton (Cordani and Teixeira, 2007). However the pre-Grenvillian history and the 123
time and mode of accretion of the Grenvillian terranes to nearby Amazonia, and correlations 124
with the alleged Laurentian conjugate margin, still remain speculative.   125

This contribution is aimed at better constraining the igneous and metamorphic history of 127
the Arequipa Massif by means of new U-Pb SHRIMP determinations and complementary 128
geochemical evidence. We conclude that the massif was the site of a complex history that129
consisted of sedimentation, magmatism and metamorphism (UHT) in the Paleoproterozoic, 130
development of a sedimentary basin in the Mesoproterozoic, Grenville-age medium- to high-131
grade metamorphism, and local metamorphic reworking and magmatism in the Early 132
Paleozoic.133
134
Geological setting135
136
The most comprehensive geological description of the Arequipa Massif is that of137
Shackleton et al. (1979). We retain here some of the domains that they distinguished to better 138
locate our samples. A summarized description follows based on their work and our own 139
observations.140
141
The northern section 142
143
The San Juán Marcona area in the north (Fig. 1) consists of a basement and a discordant 144
cover sequence. The latter is formed by glacial diamictites of the Chiquerio Formation 145
followed by a carbonate cap, the San Juán Formation, both probably Neoproterozoic (Chew et 146
al., 2007). The basement consists of banded migmatitic gneisses and minor fine-grained 147
gneisses, strongly dismembered concordant pegmatites, concordant and discordant 148
amphibolite dykes, and a foliated megacrystic granite of ca. 1790 Ma (Loewy et al., 2003). 149
Late granitic plutons cutting the discordance are Ordovician (Loewy et al., 2003). The Atico 150

domain, between Atico and Ocoña is medium-grade, with staurolite (+andalusite; Shackleton 151
et al., 1979) schists, grey metasandstones, variably retrogressed amphibolites and concordant 152
pegmatite sheets. Southward, this domain merges into a low-grade zone, the Ocoña phyllonite 153
zone, that consists of strongly strained greenish chlorite-muscovite schists, grey 154
metasandstones, quartz veins and concordant foliated pegmatite bodies. Shear bands, i.e., S-155
C´ structures, are widespread and suggest that this is a shear zone with a top-to-the-NE sense 156
of movement. Relics of an older foliation with discordant pegmatite dykes are locally 157
preserved in strain shadows, outside which pegmatites are transposed to parallelism with the 158
shear foliation. This shear zone was attributed to Paleozoic tectonism, probably Devonian, on 159
structural grounds only (Shackleton et al., 1979). However, one foliated granite within the 160
zone yielded an Ordovician age of ca. 464 Ma that is argued by Loewy et al. (2003) as shortly 161
prior to the low-grade metamorphism (M3). The large Atico igneous complex consists in large 162
part of diorites variably retrogressed to chlorite - epidote - albite, and abundant pegmatite 163
dykes. This complex, along with its southern prolongation in the Camaná Igneous Complex,164
was attributed an age of ca. 450 Ma by Shackleton et al. (1979) on the basis of a combined 165
Rb-Sr whole-rock isochron. 166
167
The southern section 168
169
The Camaná–Mollendo domain is the largest one and consists of high-grade rocks that 170
underwent granulite facies UHT metamorphism, with a paragenesis containing 171
orthopyroxene+sillimanite+quartz and sapphirine+quartz (Martignole and Martelat, 2003). It 172
consists for the most part of monotonous banded migmatitic gneisses formed by variably 173
restitic mesosomes and alternating leucosomes (Fig. 2a). Augen-gneisses are found locally,174
such as near Mollendo, that probably formed by stretching of banded migmatites within 175

strongly strained shear zones. Peneconcordant but unstrained muscovite pegmatite sheets are 176
irregularly distributed throughout the domain, more abundant in the north and northwest 177
between Quilca and Camaná. Foliation is very regular over long distances. However changes 178
in dip and strike can be mapped on a regional scale due to large upright post-foliation folds.179
Small-scale (cm to m) syn-foliation folds are locally found.180
181
The Ilo domain 182
183
The southernmost Ilo domain is separated from the main massif by a cover of Mesozoic 184
and Cenozoic sedimentary rocks. This domain is a medium- to low-grade shear zone with 185
strongly retrogressed igneous protoliths. The main facies is reddish, variably foliated,186
porphyritic granite. Boudins of coarse anorthosite that resulted from stretching of older larger 187
bodies are aligned within the foliated porphyritic granite. A third facies consists of narrow 188
bands, parallel to foliation, of a dark fine-grained mylonitic rock that contains irregularly 189
distributed feldspar porphyroclasts. Contacts are sharp or gradual. Some bands look like 190
sheared porphyritic granites; others as appear to be derived from dykes that underwent local 191
mingling with the host granite. Strain increases from anorthosite through the dark bands to the 192
granite; mylonitic foliation is common (Fig. 2b). Martignole et al. (2005) considered the 193
protoliths to be part of a Grenvillian AMCG suite.   194
195
196
Sampling and petrographic description197
198
Out of a larger sampling of the whole massif from San Juán down to Ilo, eight samples 199
were chosen for U-Pb SHRIMP dating of zircons and eight for Nd isotope composition. Two 200

complex geological history of this basement and particularly to constrain the age of the 202
Grenvillian tectonothermal event. Because of the tectonic implications and the expected 203
influence of the alleged Grenvillian anorthosite magmatism in UHT metamorphism (e.g., 204
Arima and Gower, 1991, and references therein) one target was the anorthosite and allied 205
rocks from Ilo. Determining the protoliths of many of the metamorphic rocks was difficult, 206
particularly for the highly recrystallized rocks of the Camaná–Mollendo domain, and so five 207
high-grade gneisses from this domain were also analysed for REE.208
209
Sample locations are shown in Fig. 1. Coordinates, description, abbreviated mineralogy 210
and the analytical work carried out on each sample are shown in Table 1. More detailed 211
petrographic descriptions of the rocks can be found in Supplementary Table 1, obtainable212

Analytical methods216

REEs were analysed at ACTLABS (Canada) by ICP-MS (Table 4). Samples for Sr and Nd 218
isotope analysis were crushed and powdered to ~ 200 mesh. Powders were first decomposed 219
in 4 ml HF and 2 ml HNO3 in Teflon digestion bombs for 48 hours at 120 ºC, and finally in 220
6M HCl. Elemental Rb, Sr, Sm and Nd  were determined by isotope dilution using spikes 221
enriched in 87Rb, 84Sr, 149Sm and 150Nd. Ion exchange techniques were used to separate the 222
elements for isotopic analysis. Rb, Sr and REE were separated using Bio-Rad AG50 x 12 223
cation exchange resin. Sm and Nd were further separated from the REE group using Bio-224
beads coated with 10% HDEHP. All isotopic analyses were carried out on a VG Sector 54 225

U-Pb analyses were performed on eight samples using SHRIMP RG at the Research School 230
of Earth Sciences, The Australian National University, Canberra. Zircon fragments were 231
mounted in epoxy together with chips of the Temora reference zircon, ground approximately 232
half-way through and polished. Reflected and transmitted light photomicrographs, and 233
cathodo-luminescence (CL) SEM images, were used to decipher the internal structures of the234
sectioned grains and to target specific areas within the zircons. Each analysis consisted of 6 235
scans through the mass range. The data were reduced in a manner similar to that described by 236
Williams (1998, and references therein), using the SQUID Excel macro of Ludwig (2001). U-237
Pb data are in Supplementary Table 2 obtainable from the Journal of South American Earth 238
Sciences Data Files 2#. Results are shown in Figs 3-5 and described below.239

Eighteen points were analysed including rims and cores. Nine cores yielded 207Pb/206Pb 250
ages between 1210 and 1813 Ma. If analyses with discordance > 10% are rejected (#12 & 251
#17), the remaining spots plot near Concordia and yield a mean 207Pb/206Pb age of 1796±13 252
Ma (MSWD = 1.5), which is interpreted as the crystallization age of the igneous protolith. 253
The high Th/U values of cores (0.32–0.34), typical of igneous zircons, reinforce this 254
interpretation. Rims are high-U (mostly over 1000 ppm) and with very low Th/U values 255
(mostly <0.2) typical of a metamorphic origin. Rim analyses plot on a discordia with an upper 256
intercept at 1033±23 Ma and a lower intercept at 469±70Ma; taken as the ages of Grenvillian 257
metamorphism and early Paleozoic overprint, respectively. The latter gave rise to more 258
pronounced Pb-loss in the Grenvillian rims than in the relict cores.    259

OCO-26. Meta-sandstone (Fig. 3b). The zircons from this sample are mostly equant, round 261
to sub-round grains that range up to 200 µm in diameter but with many less than 50–100µm.  262
The grains are generally clear and colourless, with only some clouded grains, and some that 263
may be frosted due to surface transport.  The CL images reveal a complex internal structure 264
(Fig. 3b).  Many grains comprise a zoned igneous centre, overgrown by metamorphic zircon 265
with homogeneous CL.  Also common are grains with metamorphic central areas with lighter 266
or darker CL outermost metamorphic zircon.  Some grains have multiple stages of zircon 267
growth, the outermost invariably being a bright CL metamorphic rim.268

uncorrected for common Pb).  The relative probability plot shows a major peak at 1000 Ma, 273
with slightly younger subordinate groups of analyses at ca. 940 Ma and ca. 840 Ma, a 274

The data giving the youngest ages tend to plot above the Concordia curve in the Tera-282
Wasserburg diagram (not shown), in part forming a Pb-loss discordia.  These areas are 283
considered to have lost radiogenic Pb and are not interpreted as reflecting Neoproterozoic 284

outer areas and rims to structured grains record mean that a case can be made for 286

On the basis of this interpretation, peak metamorphism occurred at ca. 1000 Ma and the 289
sedimentary protolith may well have formed between this time and the next oldest minor peak 290
at ca. 1200 Ma, i.e., Late Mesoproterozoic.291

Twenty-four areas were analysed on 21 zircon grains covering the range of internal CL 300
structures, and yielding a bimodal distribution. In general the zoned igneous zircon yields 301
older Proterozoic dates, whereas the more homogeneous metamorphic areas yield Grenvillian 302
dates. But this is not always the case: the outer more homogeneous areas on grains #16 and 303
#18 both yield older Proterozoic dates, whilst the weakly zoned area analysed on grain #17 is 304
Grenvillian in age. Centres and rims were analysed on grains #10, #15 and #21. Both areas 305
on grain #10 yield concordant Grenville dates, though the irregularly zoned core (#10.2) is 306
older than the homogeneous metamorphic rim (#10.1). The irregularly zoned core of grain 307
#15 is ca. 1960 Ma whereas the homogeneous rim is ca. 1050 Ma. The zoned core of grain 308
#21 is ca. 1890 Ma, with the homogeneous rim Grenvillian at ca. 1040 Ma.309

Overall, the older group consists of igneous and perhaps metamorphic core zircon with a 311
range of nearly concordant 207Pb/206Pb ages of 1760 –1950 Ma, but with a composite peak at312
ca. 1900 Ma. The Grenvillian metamorphic group is rather variable with, at the older end, one 313
concordant age at 1125 Ma and one less so at ca. 1210 Ma, and at the younger end, two 314
206Pb/238U  ages less than 1000 ma that probably indicate either Pb-loss of Grenvillian areas or 315
a superimposed thermal event peaking at ca. 980 Ma. The weighted average of the six 316
remaining 206Pb/238Pb ages is 1040±11 (MSWD = 0.90), which is taken as the peak of 317
Grenvillian metamorphism.318

ILO-20. Dark mylonitic gneiss (Fig. 5b).  The zircons from this sample are mostly slender, 400
elongate grains with subhedral terminations.  More equant and bulkier elongate grains are also 401
present, tending to be coarser-grained, up to 250µm in length and 50µm in width. The CL 402
images show a complex internal structure.  Whilst many grains have length-parallel zoning 403
(interpreted as igneous), more homogeneous, possibly metamorphic, zircon is present both as 404

Twenty-six areas were analysed on 21 grains ( Fig. 5b). A wide range of the internal 407
structures noted above were analysed, with both the zoned igneous and the more 408
homogeneous areas interpreted as metamorphic analysed on a number of single grains.  The 409
resulting data form a dispersed grouping that is dominantly within uncertainty of the Tera-410
Wasserburg Concordia.  Two analyses, #2.2 and #6.1, are more enriched in common Pb; the 411
former yields a young 206Pb/238U date of ca. 438 Ma and the area analysed is considered to 412
have lost radiogenic Pb.  The relative probability plot of 206Pb/238U ages shows a dominant 413
bell-shaped peak, which yields a weighted mean age of 464±4 (MSWD = 1.07). It is 414
noteworthy that this grouping includes both zoned igneous and the more homogeneous zircon 415
areas; thus the igneous emplacement and subsequent metamorphic developments in these 416
grains occurred within the analytical uncertainty of 464 Ma. On the older age side, there is a 417
subordinate grouping around ca. 480 Ma (four analyses give a mean of 483±7 Ma) and 418
scattered older dates to ca. 512 Ma.  The central areas to a number of grains were analysed as 419
it was originally presumed that this rock would yield a Grenvillian age.  However, whilst 420
there are scattered analyses older than the dominant Ordovician peak, there is no evidence for 421
such a Grenville event.422

ILO-23. Anorthosite (Fig. 5c). Only a few zircon grains were separated from this sample (7 424
on the probe mount). They are elongate and range from clear subhedral forms to dark, 425

Seven areas were analysed on 6 grains; they have high U ranging from 1700 to 3065 ppm, 429
with relatively moderate Th and Th/U ratios in the range 0.08 –0.21. This is on the slightly 430
low side for normal igneous zircon but may reflect late-stage magmatic crystallisation or 431
partial melting. The areas analysed are low in common Pb, but not ideal in terms of zircon 432
clarity or good CL structure. The relative probability plot for the limited number of analyses 433
is irregular, with one clearly older analysis and some skew to the young age side. A weighted 434

Pegmatites439
440
Because Rb is strongly fractionated in muscovite relative to Sr, the 87Sr/86Sr ratio in the 441
mineral increases very quickly time and the calculated age is insensitive to the assumed initial 442
values for calc-alkaline magmas. The ages of two muscovite samples obtained in this way 443
were 1000 and 1100 Ma (Table 3), i.e., Grenvillian. These pegmatites, although roughly 444
concordant to their host rocks, do not show evidence for ductile deformation and/or 445
superimposed metamorphism, and the Rb-Sr ages are taken as dating magmatic 446
crystallization.447

REE and Nd isotope data450
451
REE data for five samples of high-grade gneisses from the Camaná–Mollendo domain 452
(Table  4) are plotted in Fig. 6. They show enrichment in LREE relative to HREE, with 453
(La/Yb)N values between 13.5 and 24, and a small negative Eu anomaly (Eu/Eu* = ca. 0.8). 454
REEs patterns are remarkably similar in the five gneisses suggesting that they were all 455
derived from the same type of protolith. They are also strikingly similar to those of shales, 456
e.g., the North American Shale Composite (Taylor and McLennan, 1988), so that it may be457
inferred that the gneisses were derived from detrital sedimentary rocks. The small differences 458
among the five rocks analysed here may be attributed to variable melt extraction during 459
migmatization.   460
461
Nd isotope composition is available for the five high-grade gneisses (Table 2). They 462
yielded Ndt values of -5.5 to -8.2 at the reference age of 1700 Ma. Nd single-stage depleted-463
mantle model ages (TDM, DePaolo et al. 1981) range between ca. 2.3 and 2.5 Ga.464
465
Nd isotope composition is also available for three meta-igneous rocks from the Ilo domain. 466
Ndt values at the reference age of 475 Ma (Table 2) differ significantly from one rock to 467
another: -6.4 (ILO-19), -7.8 (ILO-20) and -3.6 (ILO-23), the latter being for the anorthosite. 468
The value for ILO-20, the mafic gneiss, is less primitive than that of the granite, perhaps 469
indicating different protoliths and not only strain differences between the two rocks as might 470
be argued from field evidence alone. 471

Discussion473
474
Two views emerge from these data. 1) The geological history of the Arequipa massif 475
covers a very long period of time, between Paleoproterozoic and Early Paleozoic 476
(Ordovician–Silurian). 2) Three main rock-forming events took place, at widely separated 477
times: in the Paleoproterozoic, in the Late Mesoproterozoic and in the Paleozoic.     478
479
The Paleoproterozoic. An old orogenic history480
481
The protolith of the strongly retrogressed quartzose gneiss MAR-8 from the San Juán482
Marcona domain was a felsic igneous rock, probably volcanic or subvolcanic. Its age of483
1796±13 Ma (Late Paleoproterozoic) coincides with a discordia upper intercept age of 484
1793±6 Ma found by Loewy et al. (2004) for a retrogressed foliated megacrystic granite 485
nearby (sample U/Pb-3). The age of ca. 1.79 Ga thus corresponds to an event of felsic 486
magmatism. Moreover, this age constrains the age of the host metasedimentary rocks that 487
were coeval or older.488
489
Migmatitic gneisses of the Camaná–Mollendo domain, although separated from the San 490
Juán domain by the Atico medium-grade rocks and the Ocoña Phyllonite zone, probably 491
correspond to the same geological domain, although they are generally less retrogressed and 492
appear to contain material older than the igneous protolith in the San Juán Marcona domain. 493
Most of the migmatitic gneisses are probably metasedimentary, as inferred from both the 494
similarity of their REE pattern to those of shales and the high peraluminosity evidenced by 495
the mineral compositions (Martignole & Martelat, 2003).  496

All the samples contain Paleoproterozoic zircons that underwent a metamorphic overprint 498
of Grenvillian age. Low-discordance Paleoproterozoic ages range from 1.76 to 2.1 Ga. A few 499
scattered Archaean zircons were also found (ca. 2.7 Ga in CAM-7, ca. 2.9 Ga in MOL-17).500
Moreover, the Paleoproterozoic ages embrace detrital cores with relict igneous zoning and501
thick subrounded, homogeneous or weakly concentrically-zoned, overgrowths (mantles). The 502
latter features are common in high-grade metamorphic zircons (Vavra et al., 1999; Corfu et 503
al., 2003). Most of the analysed areas were overgrowths, most of them with Th/U values 504
higher than most metamorphic zircons (which tend to have values < 0.1). This fact however 505
has been also recognized in other high-grade metamorphic areas (e.g., Goodge et al., 2001) 506
and, of particular relevance, in UHT metamorphic regions, e.g., in the Napier Complex, 507
Antarctica (Carson et al., 2002). Such high Th/U values in metamorphic mantles are attributed 508
to U-depletion during UHT metamorphism prior to zircon growth (Black et al., 1986; Carson 509
et al., 2002). We propose that the zircon overgrowths in the Arequipa massif migmatitic 510
gneisses probably resulted from UHT metamorphism in the Paleoproterozoic.511
512
  Samples CAM-2 and CAM-7 contain detrital igneous cores of 1890 Ma to 2080 Ma that,513
along with the few Archaean cores referred to above, suggest magmatic events in the source 514
area of the sedimentary protoliths in the Middle Paleoproterozoic (Rhyacian and Orosirian) 515
and in the Archaean. Most of the analysed zircon areas plot on discordias resulting from Pb-516
loss during Grenvillian metamorphism, and as most correspond to mantles on older cores, the 517
upper intercept ages probably date metamorphism. The strongest cases are for samples QUI-518
16 and MOL-17, where only overgrowths were considered for regression; the resulting ages 519
are 1861±32 Ma and 1892±62 Ma, respectively. Thus a metamorphic event at ca. 1.87 Ga is 520
inferred for the Paleoproterozoic overgrowths. Whether these Paleoproterozoic overgrowths 521
formed in situ or were detrital is more difficult to assess. Zircon grains in samples QUI-16 522

The Atico domain: a Mesoproterozoic sedimentary basin.553
554
The only sample from this medium-grade metamorphic domain (OCO-26) shows 555
similarities to the migmatitic gneisses of the Camaná–Mollendo domain, but also significant 556
differences. Many low-discordance areas yield ages between 1700 and 2030 Ma and a few are557
Archaean, between 2600 and 2800 Ma (one discordant age ca. 3100 Ma). These ages are from558
detrital igneous cores and metamorphic mantles, and are similar to the Proterozoic to 559
Archaean low-discordance ages found in the Camaná–Mollendo and San Juán domains. On 560
the other hand, OCO-26 contains zircons with nearly concordant ages between ca. 1200 and 561
ca. 1600 Ma. This group of ages has not been recognized in the high-grade domains; we 562
interpret these zircons as detrital. Grenvillian metamorphism started at ca. 1000 Ma.563
564
Deposition of the sedimentary protolith of OCO-26 occurred between ca. 1200 and565
ca.1000 Ma, i.e., in the Late Mesoproterozoic. Detrital zircons were fed from a source area 566
similar to the high-grade Camaná–Mollendo and San Juán domains, but also from an567
unknown source that provided the Mesoproterozoic zircons of 1200–1600 Ma. The Atico 568
domain can thus be interpreted as a sedimentary basin deposited on a Paleoproterozoic high-569
grade basement consisting of igneous and metamorphic rocks. Cobbing et al. (1977) first 570
considered the Atico metasedimentary rocks to be younger than the Mollendo high-grade 571

The Grenville-age metamorphic event575
576
All the zircon populations from the San Juán, Atico and Camaná-Mollendo samples show 577
the imprint of a metamorphic event Late-Mesoproterozoic to Early Neoproterozoic in age. 578
This metamorphism produced Pb-loss on both older zircon igneous cores and on 579
Paleoproterozoic overgrowths, giving rise to linear discordias, and probably new overgrowths 580
in the form of contrasting luminescence rims. Recorded Grenvillian ages can be bracketed 581
between ca. 940 and ca. 1080 Ma, taking age uncertainties into account. In the Camaná-582
Mollendo domain Grenvillian ages are apparently older in the Quilca and Camaná samples 583
(CAM-2: 1040±11 Ma; CAM-7: 1026±32 Ma; QUI-16: 1011±73 Ma) than in the Mollendo 584
sample (MOL-17: 940±6 Ma), a fact that was also recognized by Wasteneys et al. (1995; 585
point C: 966±5 Ma) and by Loewy et al. (2004; sample U/Pb-2: 935±14 Ma). Sample MAR-8 586
from the San Juán Marcona domain yielded an age of 1033±23 Ma for the Grenvillian event, 587
i.e., within error of those of the southern Camaná-Mollendo domain. The weighted average 588
age of metamorphism in northern Camaná–Mollendo and San Juán Marcona is 1037±19 Ma. 589
In the Atico domain we found a spread of Grenvillian ages between ca. 1000 and ca. 840 Ma. 590
The latter domain underwent only Grenvillian metamorphism, in contrast with the Camaná–591
Mollendo domain, which besides Grenvillian metamorphism underwent an older 592
Paleoproterozoic event. Martignole and Martelat (2003) carried out chemical dating of 593
monazites from the Camaná–Mollendo domain and found a spread of Grenvillian ages; 594
statistically meaningful ages of ca. 1000 Ma were obtained for three samples near Camaná. 595
Moreover, muscovite pegmatites, probably migmatitic melts, were emplaced during the 596

Grenville-age metamorphism at Arequipa took thus place in as many as three separate 600
episodes: 1) ca. 1040 Ma in the Quilca and Camaná areas of the Camaná–Mollendo domain, 601
and in the San Juán Marcona domain, 2) at 940±6 Ma in the Mollendo area of the Camaná-602
Mollendo domain; 3) between ca. 1000 and 840 Ma in the Atico domain. This evidence 603
suggests that in the Arequipa massif metamorphic domains are juxtaposed that underwent 604
Grenvillian metamorphism at different times and had different cooling histories. 605
606
It is difficult to distinguish the effects of the Grenvillian metamorphic overprint on the 607
older UHT paragenesis. Martignole & Martelat (2003), although favouring a single 608
metamorphism of Grenville-age, leave this question open, suggesting that this might 609
correspond to the lowest-P event (T<900ºC) they recognized. In our hypothesis that the UHT 610
metamorphism in Arequipa was Paleoproterozoic, temperatures attained during Grenvillian 611
metamorphism had to be high enough to completely reset the Th-U-Pb system in monazites 612
(ca. 730ºC; Copeland et al., 1988; Parrish, 1990) unless the monazite formed only during the 613
Grenvillian event. Moreover Grenville-age Ms-pegmatites are evidence for renewed partial 614
melting at this time. Temperatures between 730º and 900ºC were thus probably attained 615
during Grenvillian metamorphism in the Camaná–Mollendo domain. In the Atico domain616
however, Grenvillian metamorphism only attained P-T values within the stability field of 617
staurolite+andalusite (Shackleton et al., 1979) implying a low-pressure type of 618
metamorphism.619

In the Ilo domain, zircons from the mylonitic dark gneiss and mylonitic porphyritic granite 652
record evidence of overprinting at 430–440 Ma that could be related to retrogression within 653

zones played a significant role in metamorphism. Large areas of the Arequipa massif,659
however, do not record any evidence of Paleozoic metamorphism. 660

Correlations and geodynamic implications662
663
There is agreement that the Laurentia and Amazonia cratons were juxtaposed across the 664
Grenvillian orogenic belt at the end of Rodinia amalgamation at ca. 1.0 Ga (e.g., Dalziel, 665
1997; Davidson, 1995; Loewy et al., 2003; Tohver et al., 2004; Li et al., 2008). Models differ 666
however on the relative position of these cratons, either in the NE (relative to present-day 667
North America) or in the SE. Fig. 7 shows a paleomagnetically-constrained paleogeography at668
ca. 1.2 Ga, i.e., the alleged age of collision, according to Tohver et al. (2004). It shows the 669
location of the Grenville belt of North America and its alleged counterpart along the western 670

673
The Arequipa massif is a Paleoproterozoic inlier overprinted by the Grenvillian orogeny. 674
Correlation with other Paleoproterozoic terranes in Laurentia or Amazonia is hindered by the 675
isolation of the Arequipa massif. Compared with the ages of Paleoproterozoic orogenies in 676
Laurentia (e.g., Goodge & Vervoort, 2006, fig. 1; Goodge et al., 2004, fig. 16) the age interval 677
1.76–2.1 Ga of Paleoproterozoic zircon in the San Juán and Camaná–Mollendo domains 678
embraces the Yavapai orogeny (1.7–1.8 Ga) and the Penokean and Trans-Hudson orogenies 679
(1.8–2.0 Ga; Schulz & Cannon, 2007; Whitmayer and Karlstrom, 2007). If formerly part of 680
Laurentia, the Arequipa massif would be a relic of the pre-Grenvillian southern margin of the 681
continent (present coordinates) isolated from the northern Paleoproterozoic belts by younger682
juvenile accretionary belts (Mazatzal and the Granite-Rhyolite province: 1.7–1.3 Ga; Fig. 7). 683
The Laurentian connection was favoured by Wasteneys et al. (1995) and Loewy et al. (2003, 684
2004). On the other hand, rocks equivalent in age are also found in the Venturi–Tapajós belt 685
of the Amazonia craton (2.0–1.8 Ga; Cordani and Teixeira, 2007). Nevertheless, the latter is a 686
juvenile accretionary belt whilst the Arequipa massif is a block of reworked continental crust. 687
Moreover the Venturi–Tapajós belt is quite distant from the Arequipa massif even in current 688
reconstructions, which would imply a significant lateral displacement before Grenvillian 689
metamorphism.690

Accretion of the Arequipa massif to Amazonia has been attributed to the Grenvillian707
(Sunsás) orogeny (Wasteneys et al., 1995; Loewy et al., 2004). Grenvillian ages of igneous 708
rocks and metamorphism were early recognized along the southeastern margin of the 709
Amazonia craton by Priem (1971) and Lintherland et al. (1989). The latter coined the name 710
Sunsás orogeny for this tectonothermal event and attributed to it an age of ca. 1000 Ma. 711
Orogeny involved folding and metamorphism along discrete metasedimentary belts that wrap 712
around an older metamorphic core, the Rondonian–San Ignacio province (1.5–1.3 Ga; 713
Cordani and Teixeira, 2007). Tohver et al. (2004) summarized the Grenvillian history as 714
consisting of two events, an older one of Laurentia–Amazonia collision (1.2–1.12 Ga), and a 715
younger one of alleged oblique convergence and intracontinental strike-slip at ca. 1.1716
(Sunsás–Aguapei–Nova Brasilandia orogeny). The second event was accompanied by 717
magmatism and metamorphism within the metasedimentary belts. Metamorphism was mostly 718
of low grade but also reached granulitic facies (at Nova Brasilandia), dated at 1.09 Ga with 719
cooling through 920 Ma. Precise U-Pb SHRIMP ages led Boger et al. (2005) to constrain720

In the Grenville province of Canada the Grenvillian orogenic cycle started at ca. 1.25 Ga 729
and ended at ca. 850 Ma (Davidson, 1995, Rivers, 1997). Between 1100 and ca. 980 Ma, the 730
orogenic cycle involved two contractional episodes: the widespread penetrative Ottawan 731
orogeny (1080–1020 Ma) and the more localized Rigolet event (1000–980 Ma). In a recent 732
interpretation of the crustal-scale orogenic evolution of the Grenville province, Rivers (2008) 733
argued that collapse of the Ottawan thickened orogen took place during the time interval 734
1050–1020. Former contractional structures were reworked in extension and AMGC 735
complexes were intruded that heated the middle crust. Horst-and-graben structures developed 736
at this time in the upper crust. During the time interval 1020–950 Ma the Grenville province 737
underwent contraction at the Grenville front. The hinterland however underwent protracted 738
extensional collapse over this period with development of extensional shear zones, deep 739
ductile detachments and metamorphism (Rivers, 2008).     740
741

orogenic cycle events are not recognized in the Arequipa massif. However, the coincidence of 743
the Arequipa massif Grenvillian metamorphic ages of 1040–840 Ma with protracted extension744
both in the Laurentian Grenville orogen (except for the localized Rigolet pulse at ca. 1.0 Ga)745

included anorthosites was not involved in the Grenvillian metamorphism. Grenvillian 757
metamorphic domains with different P-T-t histories were probably juxtaposed across low-758
grade shear zones in the Ordovician–Silurian.759
760
761
Conclusions762
763
The Arequipa massif is a Paleoproterozoic inlier in the South American Grenville-age 764
orogen. It was probably part of a larger continental block that also included the Río Apa block 765
and the western Sierras Pampeanas Maz terrane. 766
767
The Paleoproterozoic pattern that emerges is one of an orogeny between ca. 1.79 and 2.1 768
Ga (Orosirian to Rhyacian) involving: a) early magmatism (between 1.89 and 2.1Ga), 769
presumably through partly Archaean continental crust, b) sedimentation of a thick sequence 770

of terrigenous sediments, c) UHT metamorphism at ca. 1.87 Ga, and d) late felsic magmatism 771
at ca. 1.79 Ga.772
773
The Atico domain can be interpreted as a sedimentary basin deposited on a 774
Paleoproterozoic high-grade basement consisting of igneous and metamorphic rocks. 775
Deposition occurred between ca. 1200 and ca.1000 Ma, i.e., in the Late Mesoproterozoic. 776
Detrital zircons were fed from a source area similar to the high-grade Camaná–Mollendo and 777
San Juán domains, but also from an unknown source that provided Mesoproterozoic zircons 778
of 1260 –1600 Ma.779
780
Grenville-age metamorphism at Arequipa took place in up to three stages: 1) ca. 1040 Ma 781
in the Quilca and Camaná areas of the Camaná–Mollendo domain, and in the San Juán 782
Marcona domain, 2) 940±6 Ma in the Mollendo area of the Camaná–Mollendo domain; 3) 783
between 1000 and 850 Ma in the Atico domain. In the Arequipa massif metamorphic domains 784
are therefore juxtaposed that underwent different Grenvillian metamorphic histories. The 785
geodynamic significance of Grenvillian metamorphism is unknown but it could be related to 786
extension and not to collision as formerly argued.787
788
During the early Paleozoic the Arequipa massif underwent magmatism at ca. 465 Ma and 789
focused retrogression along shear zones or unconformities between 430 and 440 Ma. 790
